resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

emkornfield commented on issue #4890: [WIP] ARROW-4648: [C++] Reorganize file names
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4890#issuecomment-512844601
 
 
   > "I prefer "_" for file names (which the style guide recommends as a default if there isn't a consistent pattern): 
   
   I'm also biased since I've grown accustomed to this in my day job :) 
   
   I don't think it is the case, but are there any contexts where the dashes can   be misinterpreted as flags in scripts (I don't think so, but that is the only objective  reason I can see for choosing one or the other)

pitrou commented on pull request #5069: ARROW-4648: [C++] Use underscores in source file names
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5069
 
 
   The rule is:
   - underscores in C++ source file names
   - underscores in .so / .a file names
   - hyphens in executable file names
   - hyphens in pkgconfig file names

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
Even after my eyes are used to the codebase, I still find the namings and/or code organization inconsistent.

h2. File Formats

So arrow already support a couple of file formats, namely parquet, feather, json, csv, orc, but their placement in the codebase is quiet odd:
- parquet: src/parquet
- feather: src/arrow/ipc/feather
- orc: src/arrow/adapters/orc
- csv: src/arrow/csv
- json: src/arrow/json
I might misunderstand the purpose of these sources, but I'd expect them to be organized under the same roof.

h2. Inter-Process-Communication vs. Flight

I'd expect flight's functionality from the ipc names. 

Flight's placement is a bit odd too, because it has its own codename, it should be placed under cpp/src - like parquet, plasma, or gandiva.

comments.body: There's also an inconsistent usage of `_` vs `-` in file names.
`cuda/cuda_` and `array/builder_` prefixes are also inconsistent with the rest of the "modules"

I think once we start the "C++ Dataset" project (design doc I am planning to put up on mailing list soon) we should organize the "data source" implementations as follows:

* arrow/dataset/csv
* arrow/dataset/json
* arrow/dataset/orc
* arrow/dataset/parquet

We must place these "file scanners" under a common framework or they will not be usable in the context of a query engine
There's also the issue that we don't really respect Google style guide with regards to CamelCase method names (see null_bitmap, null_count,....)
I would welcome fixing filenames (standardize on either "-" or "_" in filenames made of multiple words). Opinions?
I prefer "_" for file names (which the style guide recommends as a default if there isn't a consistent pattern): https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#File_Names
Yes, I would be in favor of underscores (with the exception of the {{-test.cc}} and {{-benchmark.cc}} endings which should IIUC continue to use hyphens)
I would strongly prefer we don't mix underscores and hyphens. It's generally more tedious to type and confusing :)
Agree with Antoine, I'd prefer hyphens.
TensorFlow is using underscores for everything including {{_test.cc}}. That seems fine to me to rename these things

Regarding file formats

* src/parquet mostly defines a standalone library fully implementing the Parquet file format, but
* src/parquet/arrow defines Arrow-Parquet conversions. This should probably be moved to src/arrow/datasets/parquet or similar, along with datasets/csv, datasets/json, datasets/orc, etc. As one caveat around this, the symbols in parquet/arrow are exported in libparquet.so, so while it is probably better for them all to end up in a libarrow_datasets.so or something, we will need to have some kind of transitional plan

One thing of note is that we install utilities such as "parquet-reader" and we probably don't want to change their names. It's a bit bothersome if the corresponding C++ sources as "tools/parquet/parquet-reader.cc" get renamed with underscores.
